title: Resettling Jerusalem
shortSummary: Nehemiah 11 details the repopulation of Jerusalem after the exile, emphasizing the voluntary commitment of leaders and people to dwell in the holy city. It lists the families and tribes who settled in Jerusalem and the surrounding towns, highlighting the organization and dedication necessary to restore the city as God's dwelling place.
timeline: c. 445 BC - Post-exilic period during Nehemiah's governorship

keyCharacters.name: Nehemiah
keyCharacters.description: Governor of Judah who led the effort to rebuild Jerusalem and organize its repopulation.

keyCharacters.name: Jedaiah
keyCharacters.description: A priest mentioned as ruler of the house of God, overseeing temple duties in Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Mattaniah
keyCharacters.description: A Levite leader who began the thanksgiving in prayer, responsible for worship in the temple.

keyCharacters.name: Pethahiah
keyCharacters.description: A leader from the tribe of Judah who served at the king's hand, managing affairs concerning the people.

definitions.definition: Temple servants assigned to assist the Levites in the service of the house of God.
Gatekeepers responsible for guarding the entrances of the temple and city.
A biblical method of decision-making or selection believed to reflect God's will.
Men noted for their courage and strength, often serving as leaders or warriors.

outline.heading: Organization of Jerusalem's Inhabitants
outline.description: The chapter opens with the rulers living in Jerusalem and the casting of lots to bring one out of every ten to dwell in the city, showing a voluntary and orderly repopulation of the holy city.

outline.heading: Listing of Families and Leaders in Jerusalem
outline.description: Detailed genealogies and numbers of the sons of Judah, Benjamin, priests, Levites, and Nethinims who settled in Jerusalem, highlighting the restoration of temple service and civil leadership.

outline.heading: Distribution of the People in Judah's Cities
outline.description: The chapter concludes with the listing of towns and villages where the rest of the people, including Levites and other tribes, dwelt, emphasizing the spread of God's people throughout the land.

application: Commit to serving God willingly, just as the people offered themselves to dwell in Jerusalem for His purposes.
Recognize the importance of organized leadership and community in fulfilling God’s work.
Value the role of worship and temple service as central to spiritual life and community restoration.
Trust God’s providence in decisions, as seen in the casting of lots to determine who would live in Jerusalem.

keyVerses.text: And the rulers of the people dwelt at Jerusalem: the rest of the people also cast lots, to bring one of ten to dwell in Jerusalem the holy city, and nine parts to dwell in other cities.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the deliberate and God-ordained repopulation of Jerusalem, underscoring the holiness of the city and the people's commitment.

keyVerses.text: And the people blessed all the men, that willingly offered themselves to dwell at Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the voluntary spirit and blessing upon those who chose to live in the city for God’s glory.

keyVerses.text: For it was the king's commandment concerning them, that a certain portion should be for the singers, due for every day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the importance of continual worship and the provision made for those who lead in praise.
